div.p:
Since the Supreme Court’s
school desegregation decision in
1954, the University has slowly
dropped all racial tones from its
hiring, housing and admissions
policies.

In 1964 the Board of Regents
ordered that questions of race
be deleted from application
forms. A student's race could
be requested only after he had
been admitted to the University,
and then only for statistical pur- posespurposes.

The housing office also deleted
race questions from its forms,
but continued to request pictures
of students seeking dormitory
rooms. Negro students felt this
was done to avoid inter-racialinterracial
room assignments. Though such
a policy was never spelled out,
observation indicated this to be
true.

Under housing policies initiat- edinitiated
this fall, no student’s picture
is requested. Housing Director
Margaret Lloyd said that previous
housing directors might have
used the pictures to match up
Negro roommates, but her
present policy forbids such “sub- jectivesubjective"
assignments.
“It is my determination that
we eliminate anything that smacks
of discrimination," Miss Lloyd
declared. “I can’t see that the
color of the skin has anything
more to do with a person than
the color of their hair."

Roommates, she explained, are
at present matched objectively.
“If you don’t request a room- materoommate
and a hall, you are assigned
by electronic data processes."
The computer, she noted, is a
“random" not a “racial" machine.

If a white student rooming with
a Negro complains of “roommate
incompatibility" due to race, Miss
Lloyd handles this complaint
much as she would any other. The
students are asked to try to work
things out. But if the situation
remains unstatisfactory, the
"complaining student is moved."
Miss Lloyd added that such
problems are often “more pa- rentalparental
than student," and arise
infrequently.

Off-campus housing is another
matter. Negroes have always
had difficulty securing rooms
and apartments near campus.
According to the testimony of
Bill Jones, a commuter, he and
another Negro submitted an ap- plicationapplication
in person for an apart- mentapartment,
leaving a $5O room deposit.
Hearing no word after a month,
“we called H.G. Smithy Realtors
and they in turn said ‘hold on a
minute.' No one ever came back
to the phone," related Jones.

"A week later, we received
(through the mall) our request for
application—-denied. We called,
and a week later our check came
back. We had no time to raise
any issues about it.

"After that, well, I just stayed
in Washington with my aunt."

According to off-campus hous- inghousing
director Doyal P. Royal, the
University aids students seeking
off-campus housing by keeping a
"public list of public facilities."
However, until last July that list
included many houses and apart- mentsapartments
that were closed to colored students.

Months of protests, picket lines,
pressure groups and politics
forced the University to revise
its “public" list over the summer
of 1966. A new form, sent out
to area landlords, stated:
“We cannot accept your listing
if your only reason for not accept- ingaccepting
the student is because of race,
color, national origin or reli- gionreligion."

Reflecting on the new policy,
Royal said, “Last summer we
decided to try to please every- bodyeverybody
and neutralize the card."
As a result, last year's 400-
apartment list has dwindled.
"Only one large apartment house
remains on the list," he said.

Removed from housing office
policies is the University's ath- leticsathletics
program. In his depart- mentdepartment,
asserted Director of
Athletics William W. Cobey, “the
policy has been simply that any
student enrolled at the University
is welcome to come out for
athletics." Ball players are not
chosen by their color, they must
qualify academically and athleti- callyathletically.

Furthermore, the athletic de- partmentdepartment
keeps no record of an
athlete’s race. Cobey could not
recall the date when the first
Negro athlete competed for the
University in intercollegiate var- sityvarsity
ball. However, a perusal
of Terrapin yearbooks shows that
the swim team was the first to
integrate, in 1963, with the addi- tionadditional
of Negro swimmer Jason
Williams.

The football team followed the
next year. In fall, 1964, Darryl
Hill played on the varsity squad.
Last year in football, Ernie
Torain played halfback. He was
joined this year by Alvin Lee,
also a halfback.

Bill Jones played basketball
last year, and this year Pete
Johnson is also playing on the
court. The track team has had
Negro members since last year.

In another area, the hiring of
employees, recruitment depends
largely on state civil service
requirements.

The University is an "equal
opportunity" employer, reports
George W. Fogg, director of
personnel. "We have employed
(Negro) that is qualified
for his job. We equalize white
and Negro... We don’t favor
either one or the other."
Answering a query about the
sparsity of Negro secretaries on
campus, Fogg frankly conceded,
“We have a lot of Negro secre- tariessecretaries
—-but we have a lot more
white ones."

To recruit staff, Fogg's office
advertises through local newspa- persnewspapers
and employment agencies.
If applicants meet state civil
service requirements, they are
interviewed by the Personnel Of- ficeOffice.
Departments with vacancies
interview several job candidates
and choose one to fill the position.
Once hired, the employees must
fill out income tax papers, pay
roll forms and a personal history
questionnaire. The personal his- toryhistory
form includes a question on
race.

“This is only for statistics,"
explained Fogg. “We never ask
this until the person is hired."
These racial statistics are re- quiredrequired
by the Compliance Com- mitteeCommittee
of the State Fair Prac- ticesPractices
Commission. The Univer- sityUniversity
must make a report to the
Commission on the ratio of Negro
and white employees. The first
such report, which is presently
being compiled, is due Jan. 15.

Hiring of faculty members is
done largely at the departmental
level. Nominations are generated
by the department heads.

Here, related Fogg, qualifica- tionsqualifications
are very specific. Nomi- neesNominees
are interviewed by R.
Lee Hornbake, vice-president for
academic affairs, and appoint- mentsappointments
confirmed by the Board
of Regents.

Hornbake stated that in re- cruitingrecruiting
faculty, “we are not try- ingtrying
to find people of any race.
But," he added “qualified Negroes
are in very short supply, since
they are being sought after
eagerly by many instructors."

He mentioned that two Negroes
--an African assistant professor
in G and PGovernment and Politics and an associate pro- fessorprofessor
of education—-have been
hired in the past two years to
teach in College Park. However,
as for the total number of Negro
instructors on the University’s
many campuses, Hornbake said,
“I don’t know how many there
are and honestly, I don't care.
All I am interested in is good
faculty."

Hornbake also disspelled a
rumor that has been pervading
the sociology department for the
last twelve months. A Negro
professor nominated by the
sociology department did not
complete his contract negotia- tionsnegotiations
for a position. Rumors,
however, persisted that the ad- ministrationadministration
had dropped their
offer due specifically to the ap- plicant’sapplicant's
race.

Hornbake explained what
happened. The man, a “highly
recommended" professor of an- thropologyanthropology,
told the University
he had received “another offer
from a West coast institution."

“He was a quality man, who
had been in demand in a variety
of places," testified Hornbake.
“I did not infer from him that he
felt that race had been a factor
at all, in not accepting the Uni- versityUniversity
bid."

To learn just how many
Negroes the University employs
in College Park, last spring the
Personnel Office sent to all fac- ultyfaculty
and staff a short personal
history questionnaire. The data,
as mentioned before, was being
compiled for the State Fair Prac- ticesPractices
Commission.

Resenting racial questions,
many white faculty members an- sweredanswered
by writing “Eskimo" or
“mixed." But according to Fogg,
“this was a misdirected form of
liberalism. These people hinder- edhindered
the cause that they were stand- ingstanding
for."

The purpose of the survey was
to indicate that the University
does comply with the Civil Rights
Act.
